title: PQB News Year in Review : January to April 2025 | Parksville Qualicum News

PQB News Year in Review: January to April 2025
Published 10:35 am Friday, January 9, 2026
A look back at some of the major stories and issues in the PQB News from January to April of 2025. Check back for further installments and visit www.pqbnews.com for expanded year-in-review coverage
Jan. 1
Qualicum Beach council seeks province’s support to help foreign doctors get licensed
Qualicum Beach council endorsed a plan to send a letter to the B.C. Minister of Health, highlighting the need for doctors in the town and to help international physicians already in the area get licensed to practice medicine in Canada.
Javier Cabrera, who was a doctor in Colombia, appeared before council to make them aware of the difficulties they have been experiencing in getting their applications to be licensed to work as doctors.
He said currently there are six experienced doctors, trained internationally, living in the Parksville Qualicum Beach area with their families, who are in this challenging position.
RDN chair Craig joins Island Coastal Economic Trust board
The Island Coastal Economic Trust has welcomed the addition of Regional District of Nanaimo chair Vanessa Craig to its board of directors.
Craig, along with North Cowichan Mayor Rob Douglas, was appointed by members of the Central-South Island Regional Advisory Committee.
“Douglas and Craig bring a fresh perspective to our board of directors,” said Island Coastal Economic Trust chair, Michelle Staples, who is also the mayor of Duncan.
Learn to Run Program gets PQB residents hooked on running
Ewan Moir was not a big fan of running. Despite being an active person most of his life, Moir found the sport to be tiring and challenging. As well, he ended up sore the next day.
Now in his 60s, his perspective on running has changed. Moir came across a poster at local business store about Oceanside Running Club Association’s Learn to Run program. And that’s where it hit him. He quipped he is either just old or has become a bit wiser.
Moir registered for the Learn to Run Program and it was a journey that has greatly motivated him to become a runner. He got hooked.
Jan. 8
Study finds Parksville short-term rentals raised cost of rent
Short-term rentals have raised the cost of rent in Parksville, according to a study commissioned by the Parksville Qualicum Beach Tourism Association.
The report by Third Space Planning found STRs resulted in an estimated 36 lost potential homes, or two per cent of the city’s housing stock.
“We found no statistical sense in which residential STR’s are needed,” said Eric Swanson of Third Space Planning in a presentation to council. “Most of your tourist accommodation is already condo style, so amenity rich and we calculated that if residential STRs just magically disappeared the city would still have had a surplus of units during the peak month.”
6 impaired driving charges approved following death of man near Qualicum Beach
A BC Highway Patrol investigation has led to six impaired driving-related charges against a Coombs man, after a Good Samaritan died and a woman was seriously hurt in a March 2024 incident near Qualicum Beach.
The charges follow a BCHP investigation into a collision between a black SUV and a minivan that left an 80-year-old Red Deer man dead.
Cpl. Michael McLaughlin of the BC Highway Patrol noted the investigation was forwarded to the BC Prosecution Service.
Affordable housing project approved by Parksville council
An affordable housing project intended to bolster work-force housing is on its way to Parksville.
Council voted in favour of the required an official community plan (OCP) amendment and bylaw and zoning and development bylaws to allow the four-storey, 36-unit non-market rental apartment building to be constructed on the corner of Franklin’s Gull Road and the old Island Highway.
“It’s a monumental ask, to have something come to fruition like this,” said Coun. Amit Gaur.
The building will include 18 one-bedroom units, 15 two-bedrooms and three three-bedrooms units. The city-owned land at 1225 Franklin’s Gull Rd. will be leased to the society long-term.
Jan. 15
Parksville Qualicum Beach area’s highest-assessed home valued at $20.6M
Dorcas Point Road in Nanoose Bay dominated a list of the most expensive homes in the Parksville Qualicum Beach area.
The value of the average single family home in Parksville increased by one per cent to $750,000 in 2025, while in Qualicum Beach the average single family property value is now $920,000, up by two per cent, according to new data from BC Assessment.
Three homes in Nanoose Bay made it onto the Top 100 Valued Residential Properties on the Island, along with two in Qualicum Beach.
Folk duo Madison Violet return to Errington
Juno-nominees Madison Violet marked 25 years together in 2025 and were excited to play at the Errington Hall on Jan. 18.
The duo of Lisa MacIsaac and Brenley MacEachern play a style of folk music that’s difficult to place in a category, combining elements of pop, indie, bluegrass and country.
“From record to record our sound changes quite a bit, but when you see us live, that’s really who we are,” MacEachern said.
The duo joked they will have to figure something out for their 25-year silver “bandiversary”.
Oceanside Minor Baseball honours young umpires
Oceanside Minor Baseball Association recently honoured two of their young umpires.
Tracy Balfour, 12, was named junior umpire of the year by the OMBA. Despite her young age, she has shown impressive understanding of the game’s rules, according to the OMBA.
She has an outstanding demeanour and has developed exceptional game management skills.
The senior umpire of the year award was awarded to Evan Boulet, who has been an invaluable mentor to the OMBA’s junior umpires.
Jan. 22
Parksville and Qualicum Beach welcome new physicians, nurse practitioners
The City of Parksville and the Town of Qualicum Beach welcomed new physicians and nurse practitioners to their communities, improving access to health care for residents.
The mayors of both communities extended their sincere appreciation to the dedicated professionals at Central Island Division of Family Practice for the key role they play in recruiting, hosting and integrating these health care professionals into the communities.
“These are competitive times with doctor shortages experienced throughout Canada, so the successful attraction of new practitioners is even more impressive,” a joint news release said. “We look forward to our ongoing engagement with the Division and continued success in recruitment and retention of health care professionals in 2025 and beyond.”
RDN electoral areas will need close to 3,000 new homes over five years
The electoral areas in the Regional District of Nanaimo will need close to 3,000 new homes over the next five years to meet the region’s growing population.
Jamie Vann Struth, Deloitte senior manager of economic advisory, said numbers are calculated by looking at projected population and household growth over the next five years and projecting how many units are needed to meet that projected growth category.
The reported shows the total local housing needs for the combined electoral areas A to H over a 5-year period is 2,810 units and 9,469 units over a 20-year period.
Errington Elementary, B.C.’s first school of the new millennium celebrates 25 years
Errington Elementary School marked its 25th birthday on Jan. 15 and the event was extra special since EES was B.C.’s first school of the new millennium.
When the new school opened in 2000, staff and students buried a time capsule in the middle of the roundabout with a plaque to celebrate the opening. Later a tree from the old Errington Elementary was transplanted beside the new school’s playing field.
Staff and students posed for a group photo on the roundabout and sang ‘Happy Birthday’ before enjoying some birthday cake.
Qualicum Beach museum reflects on ‘successful year’
Qualicum Beach Historical and Museum Society say they have had a “very successful year.”
President Dave Ireland expressed gratitude to the support given by Mayor Teunis Westbroek and council that significantly contributed to the success of the museum
Last year, the museum recorded a total of 3,300 visitors, which aside from general admissions, include school tours and special events. It helped bring in about $8,198.40 in door donations.
Jan. 29
Town of Qualicum Beach wants railway crossing traffic controls reconfigured
With an absence of active trains travelling on the railway north of Nanaimo, the Town of Qualicum Beach wants stop signs for vehicular traffic at railway crossings located in the community removed.
Mayor Teunis Westbroek indicated there have been some enterprising residents who have turned stop signs around where vehicles are required to stop.
“There’s so little traffic and people, I believe, inherently don’t like breaking the law,” said Westbroek. “When they see a stop sign at the railway crossing when they know there’s not going to be a train, it’s really hard to stop so they go through it. And when they see the next stop sign by First Avenue, they’d go, ‘we didn’t stop for that one so we’ll just go through that one.’ It makes people uncomfortable. It does me. I know I should stop and I do because people know my car.”
Drugs, body armour and loaded firearm seized following Parksville arrest
Oceanside RCMP reported they seized a pistol, ammunition, body armour and suspected drugs believed to be possessed for the purpose of trafficking following an arrest and the search of a utility trailer in Parksville on Jan. 10.
An Oceanside RCMP traffic officer arrested a 55-year-old Parksville resident on a warrant for failing to attend court the previous day related to a charge of driving while prohibited.
Sgt. Shane Worth of the Oceanside RCMP said the man, upon his arrest, was found to be in possession of multiple types of suspected drugs which investigators believe were intended for sale.
Bailey’s in Qualicum Beach sold to new owners
Bailey’s in the Village has been a fixture in downtown Qualicum Beach for more than a quarter century, but that will soon change.
Cindy Thomson and Len Thomson plan to sell the business and retire after owning and operating the restaurant for 14 years. Both are 70, and Len said that although it’s sad to go, age is starting to catch up with him. He recently went in for a knee replacement.
A local business will take over the location, according to the owners.
Dan Smith to return as head coach for Ballenas Whalers football club
The Ballenas Whalers will have Dan Smith back as head coach next high school football season.
The University of British Columbia Hall of Fame and British Columbia Football Hall of Fame member will take over from Scott Childs, who led the Whalers in the last two BC Secondary Schools Football Association seasons.
Childs assumed the head coach position in 2022 from Jeremy Conn, who after 15 years in the Whalers program, decided to give it up for personal reasons.
Smith plans to update the Whalers’ playbook, which he is collaborating on now with coach Roger Boyer.
Feb. 5
Qualicum school board votes to close Craig Street Commons
The Craig Street Commons in Parksville will close Jan. 1, 2026, following a decision by the Qualicum School District’s board of trustees.
The facility, home to a variety of community-based activities and programs, could have been closed effective July 1, 2025, per the original motion brought before the board on Jan. 28.
An amendment by Trustee Julie Austin extended that time period, in the hopes an outside public organization would step in with a plan for the building, which is owned by the school district.
“I would like to give the opportunity for them to explore it a little further,” Austin said. “So to that end I can’t vote in favour of this motion this evening to close the commons.”
Qualicum Beach chamber sees membership grow ‘exponentially’
The Qualicum Beach Chamber of Commerce continued to grow in 2025.
Daniela Novak, president of the chamber, presented a year-end report at the Qualicum Beach council regular meeting on Jan. 22 and highlighted the ups and downs the chamber went through in 2024.
Last year, the QBCM’s membership grew and Novak said it continues to do so, “exponentially.”
“When I came on board, we had less than 120 members,” said Novak. “We are up around 200 now and we continue to grow. And those members are existing businesses as well as folks who left us and are now coming back.”
Residents invited to share stories for ‘Flying Phil’ legacy film
A local video production company is calling on residents to share their stories of ‘Flying Phil’ St. Luke, in the hope of capturing the life and legacy of the beloved community figure to be featured on film.
Johanna Osborne, owner of Pancake Pictures, said, in a news release, she’s felt called to create a film about St. Luke since before his passing in 2023.
The goal of the film is to create an intimate portrait of St. Luke’s impact on the community, capturing personal stories from young and old that highlight his spirit, generosity, and connection with the people around him.
Qualicum Beach Curling Club celebrates 60th anniversary
The Qualicum Curling Centre turned 60 years old in 2025.
The special occasion was celebrated on Jan. 25. To mark the milestone, the centre resurrected the Battle of the Sexes competition first held during the 50th anniversary of the club.
A decade ago, it was the men’s teams that lifted the trophy. This time around, it was the women who prevailed and hoisted the memorial cup, as well secured bragging rights.
Feb. 12
Cat stuck up tree for 5 days rescued by Parksville climber
When your pet cat gets stuck in a tree, who do you call? That was the dilemma Parksville residents Lorrie and Don Barbeau faced when their family cat, Boots, was stuck high up a tree near their home for five full days.
Boots remained in the tree for so long with no signs of the feline coming down from its lofty perch, 25 metres up. It was in so much distress it was continuously crying, said Lorrie.
Lorrie’s best friend in Courtenay found Ed Hazlett of The Orange Tree Service from out of the Comox Valley, who is a skilled tree climber and has done cat rescues before.
Hazlett said he had to approach the cat gently so she wouldn’t panic.
“I am a big old climber and was shaking the tree but the cat couldn’t go any higher,” Hazlett said. “And because it has been up there for so long, it was pretty weak. So I went up there and give it a little pet and get comfortable with it. Then I just grabbed it and put in my big bag, zipped it and then came down. It was pretty straightforward.”
City takes over food truck management from Parksville Chamber
The City of Parksville will take over co-ordination and management of the food trucks in the community park, following a council decision.
Council approved a recommendation to have staff conduct a one-year pilot project and report back with an analysis at the end of the 2025 summer season.
The agreement between the city and the Parksville and District Chamber of Commerce expired in October 2024 and staff were directed to review the food truck program.
The pilot will see city staff manage the food truck service’s two main pads, with the possibility of additional revenue from a third truck or car in a location such as the Gathering Plaza.
New recreation group to operate Meadowood Community Centre
Since being established in 2022, the Reginal District of Nanaimo staff has been overseeing the operations of the Meadowood Community Centre in Corcan-Meadowood and operating it on a limited scale.
That is now going to change as a new group, the Meadowood Hall Recreation Association has come forward to take over the daily operations and maintenance of the centre.
The MHRA will handle the upkeep, cleaning, managing hall bookings and paying the invoicing related to the day-to-day operations of the hall.
Nanoose Bay blacksmith crafts lifelike octopus sculpture
Nanoose Bay blacksmith Dave Kasprick became interested in octopuses over the years he encountered them as a commercial fisherman, and lately he’s started creating art in their likeness.
His latest commission is a lifelike sculpture of an octopus and he estimated it is approximately 36 inches wide.
“If you were to stretch the tentacles out it would probably be over seven feet,” said Kasprick, who has been blacksmithing for about 17 years. “It’s a pretty cool project.”
Feb. 19
Unhoused struggle to get through another winter without shelter in Parksville area
Unhoused people in the Parksville Qualicum Beach area were once again without a consistent overnight cold weather shelter in 2025.
Temporary overnight warming centres opened for a handful of days at the Christian Fellowship Centre in Qualicum Beach and Oceanside Community Church in Errington, but outside of that, unhoused people are left to deal with the cold.
To stay warm, they are sleeping in cars, huddling in sleeping bags in tents, living under overpasses and “couch-surfing”, according to Robin Campbell with Manna Homeless Society.
“The last two years, I’ve never seen so many women on the street and that is a shock,” Campbell said. “Older women — women of retirement age living in their cars, or living outside.”
IIO: No evidence police contributed to Parksville man’s death in July 2023
A report from the Independent Investigations Office of BC has concluded there is no evidence that any unjustified action or inaction by police contributed to the death of a Parksville man in July 2023.
The man, referred to as the “affected person” (AP) in the IIO report, was identified as John Boyce in a July 2023 news release by Oceanside RCMP.
The autopsy report indicated the cause of death was “complications of ruptured intracranial aneurysm with blunt force trauma a significant contributing factor”.
“There is no evidence that any unjustified action or inaction on the part of any officer contributed in any way to the AP’s death,” the report said.
TOSH fundraising event in Qualicum Beach nets $14K
The Old School House’s recent ‘Double Your Membership’ campaign was a big success and raised $14,000 to keep the lights on at the arts centre in Qualicum Beach.
“These funds are so important in helping us continue to run our programs and keep art alive in our community. We are beyond grateful for your support!” executive director Illana Hester said in a news release.
The arts centre relies on donors to keep its doors open and programs running.
Ping pong helps Parksville seniors deal with Parkinson’s disease
Bob Biljetina has been a member of the Parksville Table Tennis Society for four years now.
It’s an important recreational activity for the 72-year-old Parksville man as it helps him with Parkinson’s disease, a progressive brain disorder that causes movement problems, stiffness and balance issues.
Biljetina said when he was diagnosed with the debilitating disease four years ago, he refused to slow down and allow it to take control of his life.
He wanted to maintain a quality of life that is full of life, energy and positivity. He found table tennis or ping pong to be a wonderful cure.
Feb. 26
Parksville sand sculpting competition relocates for more space
The Quality Foods Sand Sculpting Competition and Exhibition moved in 2025, but not very far.
The popular event hosted by the Parksville Beach Festival Society was relocated to a section of the kite field in Parksville Community Park, next to the beach volleyball courts, following council approval on Feb. 19.
The new, larger site allows for more spectators and improve mobility access, as well as reduce congestion at main beach access locations, according to a report by Blaine Russell, director of community planning and building.
Nanoose Bay resident seeks more community involvement on cell tower site selection
A Nanoose Bay resident wants the Regional District of Nanaimo to amend its bylaw regarding placement of cellphone towers in residential areas.
Gabrielle Cameron appeared as a delegation at the RDN board meeting on Feb. 11, urging a new policy language in Bylaw 2500 that reflects the concerns of the community regarding construction of utility structures.
She also asked the board to reject Rogers Communications application to erect a new 5G tower at 1800 Serenity Pl., in Nanoose Bay.
Qualicum School District enrolment ‘plateaued’, expected to decline
Qualicum School District is looking at a challenging budget process, with costs that continue to escalate and enrolment expected to decline, according to Ron Amos, secretary-treasurer.
The decline in enrolment will likely grow with this coming year, he added, which translates into less funding from the Ministry of Education and Childcare.
“It is the demographic of our community. We talk about, and again simple terms, playground versus pickleball. We have an aging population,” Amos said during a virtual public budget information meeting on Feb. 12.
While student numbers decline, expenses are on the rise, including “replacement” costs, meaning substitute teachers, Amos said.
New Oceanside Drillers squad set to play in Vancouver Island Lacrosse League
The Vancouver Island Lacrosse League is growing.
This coming season, two new senior teams will be included, one of them the Oceanside Drillers, currently being formed by Joshua Heyd.
The other will be the Snuneymuxw Sun Devils based out of Nanaimo. Heyd said they are currently recruiting players.
The Drillers will play most of their home games at the Howie Meeker Arena at Oceanside Place
March 5
Coldest Night of the Year breaks fundraising record with $122,721 donated in PQB
It was another record year for Coldest Night of the Year Oceanside, which surpassed its fundraising record again, with $122,721 in donations.
More than 300 walkers on 39 teams marched in the cold on Feb. 22 in support of people experiencing or at risk of homelessness.
“It was an amazing night with a great turnout,” said Violet Hates, Island Crisis Care Society executive director.
Couple, pets escape blaze that destroyed home in Hilliers
No one was injured after fire destroyed a home in Hilliers in the early morning of Feb. 23.
The home is a total loss, according to Fire Chief Ron Schildroth with the Coombs-Hilliers Volunteer Fire Department.
A GoFundMe online fundraiser was launched and quicklyy raised close to $10,000.
A couple escaped from the fire with their pets, but are in need of clothes, shoes and food for themselves and their pets, including prescription food for their dog.
Emmy nominee performs at Errington Hall
World fusion composer and electronic artist Adham Shaikh has played in front of thousands at music festivals all over the world, but there’s something he loves about playing a small community hall.
“I like the smaller, more intimate atmosphere,” said Emmy Award nominee Shaikh. “I find that when we bring our shows to the local community, especially in B.C., people are very stoked.”
The group combines traditional instruments from around the world with electronic beats, synthesizers, live looping and even some improvisation.
Twins from France enjoy Canadian style of hockey with Oceanside Generals
The Save On Foods Oceanside Generals had their own version of the Sedin twins during the 2024/2025 season.
Brothers Mathias and Alexandre Alhaj are originally from Montpellier, France. They were acquired by Oceanside general manager Rick Hannibal from the Comox Valley Glacier Kings last December.
They have become more acclimatized to the style of hockey in Canada, which both acknowledge is vastly different from what they’re used to in Europe.
March 12
Qualicum School District does not intend to create pride flag policy
The Qualicum School District does not intend to create a policy regarding flying pride flags at schools.
The District Parent Advisory Council had requested the consideration of a policy that incorporates pride values, as well as visible inclusion of pride flags at all schools.
Rudy Terpstra, the district’s SOGI (Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity) lead, and director of instruction, spoke at DPAC’s Feb. 19 meeting about the district’s work to support students in recent years, including through policy, flags, professional development and the B.C. curriculum.
Terpstra said he appreciated the “sentiment” behind DPAC’s request, but he did not recommend supporting a policy.
TOSH archive project digitizes decades of PQB history
The Archive Project at the Old School House Arts Centre has seen volunteers unravel nearly 40 years of history.
Hundreds of historical documents dating back to 1987 were digitally archived, with more than 200 collective hours spent by 10 volunteers combing through news clippings, meeting minutes, newsletters, posters, arts education and photographs, according to a news release submitted by Eunice Villamayor.
“We live in a digital world and accessibility for all of our community is significant,” said Illana Hester, TOSH’s executive director told the PQB News. “Not everybody can climb the stairs here. Not everybody can come here.”
Oceanside Generals goalie Josh Nuttall earns MVP, rookie of the year titles
The Oceanside Generals recently staged their year-end banquet, honouring players who excelled during the 2024-25 Vancouver Island Junior Hockey League season. The event was held at the Rod & Gun restaurant in Parksville.
The top honour was awarded to goaltender Josh Nuttall, who was named most valuable player. He was also presented with the rookie of the year award.
Nuttall ended up with the highest save percentage in the VIJHL, at .920.
March 19
PQB leaders weigh in on economic impact of U.S. tariffs
The mayors of Parksville and Qualicum Beach hope ongoing tariff threats from the U.S. will encourage the provinces to remove trade barriers between themselves and bring about a positive longterm economic outcome.
The U.S. recently announced tariffs on billions of dollars worth of Canadian imports, under the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Free Trade Agreement, and the Canadian government has responded with counter-tariffs.
Parksville Mayor Doug O’Brien said it’s important to look for new trade agreements, be they international, or within Canada.
“The attempt by the Trump administration to destabilize and weaken the economy has only served to strengthen Canadian resolve to adjust and identify the economic opportunities,” he said.
Programs to relocate after Forward Recovery Centre closes in Parksville
Forward Recovery Centre closed its doors at the end of April 2025, but many of the services will continue on at Forward House a few blocks away on Hirst Avenue.
The recovery centre on the Alberni Highway in downtown Parksville had offered one-one-one addictions counselling for free, according to Rosemary Bonderud, president of Forward House Community Society.
The society realized last year it would need to curtail some of its services, with donations reduced during the COVID period, Bonderud added.
PQB coffee roasters win espresso World Series in Guatemala
French Press Coffee Roasters are now the world champions of espresso after taking the top prize at the Golden Bean World Series in Guatemala.
The company with locations in Parksville and Qualicum Beach took the gold for its Colombian “co-ferment”, with cherry as its base.
Owner Jeremy Perkins says he figures the judges awarded his coffee the gold on account of its balance of cherry, almond, tropic fruit flavour and a touch of chocolate, but he can’t be sure since when he spoke to the PQB News, the judges comments were not yet posted online.
March 26
Qualicum Beach aquatic centre project receives $7M federal contribution
The Regional District of Nanaimo received some assistance in the form of a $7-million contribution that will go towards the Ravensong Aquatic Centre expansion project in Qualicum Beach.
With this announcement, the pool project will be funded through the contribution, long-term borrowing if approved through a referendum on April 5, and $6 million from capital reserves.
The federal contribution will reduce the RDN’s reliance on borrowing the full amount of the proposed $30 million and provide a financial buffer during a shifting economic period.
Parksville councillor to deploy with RCAF
Parksville Coun. Amit Gaur deployed with the Royal Canadian Air Force to northern Canada in 2025.
To deploy as a reservist with the RCAF, Gaur said there are quite a few steps he must take, including permission from council.
“I serve Parksville at this table, but I also serve Canada as a reservist with the Air Force,” he said during council’s March 17 meeting. “I have an opportunity to serve on a deployment with the Air Force and the deployment starts somewhere, end of June, or early July.”
Gaur added he hopes to attend meetings virtually when he can while on his leave, which would be approximately six months.
Regional District of Nanaimo aims to create new regional trail
The Regional District of Nanaimo is looking at creating new regional trail connections that would link Top Bridge Regional Trail and the Coombs to Parksville Rail Trail.
“The RDN’s Parks and Trails strategy identified developing trail connections as a goal to improve livability of the region and well-being of its residents,” said Tom Osborne, general manager of recreation and parks.
“The E & N corridor from Englishman River to Alberni Highway is as potential connection between the existing Top Bridge Regional Trail and the Coombs to Parksville Rail Trail.”
5-pin bowlers from Parksville’s Sunset Lanes to compete at nationals in Edmonton
Two young bowlers from Parksville’s Sunset Lanes are hoping to strike gold at the Youth Bowling Canada National Championships in Edmonton.
Everett Hoff, 10, and Madi Rainforth, 9, earned a spot in the nationals that will take place May 5 to May 7 after bowling extremely well at the Youth Bowl Canada B.C. Championships in Kamloops and Chase on March 1 and March 2.
Coach Linda Raymond is excited to have both her young players head to the national championships. “It’s bantams and they’re young ones,” said Raymond. “You never know what’s going to happen next there.”
April 2
Candidates set to run for federal election in Courtenay-Alberni riding
Candidates for the April 28 federal election were announced in PQB, with Gord Johns of the NDP sitting as the incumbent.
Johns ran against Conservative Party candidate Kris McNichol, Liberal Party candidate Brian Cameron and Green Party candidate Chris Markevich.
Johns was first elected the riding’s Member of Parliament in 2015 and was the NDP critic for mental health and harm reduction before Parliament was dissolved for the election.
$10-a-day child care spaces will help parents in PQB
The Parksville Child and Family Centre is now home to 111 new $10-a-day child care spaces, as part of the province’s ChildcareBC program.
“Locally our parents are overwhelmingly thrilled. We’ve had nothing but positive and grateful messages come through,” said Ali Legge, director of operations and human resources for BGC Central Vancouver Island.
The province recently announced the new spaces, which will also include 75 childcare spaces at Qualicum Beach Elementary.
Volunteers raise awareness on distracted driving danger in Qualicum Beach
Oceanside Community Safety Volunteers were in Qualicum Beach to raise awareness about the hazards of distracted driving on March 26.
Volunteers watched and jotted down the number of drivers they saw on their phones, while they stood at the four corners of the intersection of Fern Road and Memorial Avenue.
They will report their statistics to ICBC and Oceanside RCMP. March is Distracted Driving Awareness Month, and ICBC, OCSV and Oceanside RCMP run this kind of awareness event each spring and fall in different locations across District 69.
Juno-winner Stephen Fearing returns to Errington Hall
Juno Award-winner Stephen Fearing performed at the Errington Hall on April 12.
The singer-songwriter loves telling stories through his music and con- necting with audiences across the country.
He gets a lot of ideas from the lives of other people, and even overhearing a conversation on the bus can lead to a new song.
“Inspiration comes in the weirdest times, in the weirdest ways and so my job is to pay attention and to listen,” Fearing said.
April 9
Errington Memorial Hall showcases upgrades on 103rd birthday
The historic Errington Memorial Hall celebrated its 103rd birthday by showing off the new improvements to the cultural building.
Since last May, the hall has undergone some renovations and improvements. The project cost approximately $500,000 with funding coming from federal and provincial governments as well as the Regional District of Nanaimo.
Volunteers from the hall also raised $50,000 through raffles and other fundraising endeavours.
Judge issues $1,500 fine in Qualicum Beach crash that killed Alberni woman
A Maple Ridge woman was found guilty of driving with undue care and attention in a fatal accident in Qualicum Beach.
The 35-year-old was handed a $1,500 fine at the Nanaimo Law Courts on March 31.
Deb Walton, of Port Alberni, was a passenger on a motorcycle driven by her husband Carl when they were hit by a left-turning vehicle as they entered an intersection. The bike struck the front passenger side of the Maple Ridge woman’s car. The 61-year-old was pronounced dead on the scene by paramedics. Her husband, the motorcycle driver, was also injured.
Kwalikum Kondors’ Mbobela brothers to play in hoop all-star games
Two of the Kwalikum Kondors’ top players, brothers Simon and Ben Mbobela saw action at the 36th Annual Vancouver Island Seniors Classic High-School Basketball All-Star Games.
The long-running tournament involving this year’s best graduating high-school players on Vancouver Island will take place at Spectrum Secondary on April 5.
The Kondors players, who helped Kwalikum finish fourth on the Island, will join the best players from the North Island. They will play for the North Island B All-Stars.
April 16
Voters say ‘no’ to $30M loan for Ravensong expansion
A referendum to borrow up to $30 million to expand Ravensong Aquatic Centre in Qualicum Beach failed to garner a positive outcome from voters in District 69.
The final tally of the April 5 referendum showed the ‘no’ votes at 4,487 prevailing over the ‘yes’ votes at 2,877.
Qualicum Beach Mayor Teunis Westbroek expressed disappointment with the results.
“It’s very disappointing but not surprising,” said Westbroek. “I know there are a lot of people, especially from Nanoose Bay, who at (Regional District of Nanaimo) board meetings were very upset with the tax increases and so on.”
Parksville council votes against motion to reinstate city liaison to homelessness task force
The City of Parksville does not plan to reinstate its liaison with the Oceanside Task Force on Homelessness any time soon.
Council members voted against a motion that requested the appointment of a liaison to the group which works to address homelessness and issues related to homelessness across the region.
The decision to withdraw from the task force was made during a closed meeting in October 2024.
Parksville council hears concerns regarding proposed mall development
A handful of residents brought their concerns to Parksville council regarding two bylaws to allow for a proposed mixed commercial residential development at the Wembley Mall.
Increased traffic, parking issues and the future of frogs inhabiting the future development area were all topics raised by residents during the public hearing on April 7.
The proposed five-storey building’s preliminary design shows 70 residential units, with retail space on the ground floor.

Regional District of Nanaimo board hears public concerns about coastal risks
The Regional District of Nanaimo board heard the concerns of residents regarding the impact of climate change to the region’s coastal areas.
In 2024, the RDN launched an initiative called ‘Our Changing Coast’, a four-year program that focuses on building coastal resilience throughout the district.
Key concerns were impact to private properties, impact to those community areas that everyone care about and helped build, environmental. impacts to natural areas and habitats for birds, fish and wildlife, and impact to infrastructure such as roads, power and utility services.
Residents voice opposition to plans for rehabilitation facility
Some residents are alarmed by potential plans to build a rehabilitation-type facility on Kaye Road in Nanoose Bay near Parksville.
They raised their objections at the Regional District of Nanaimo board’s regular meeting on April 8.
The Delancey Street BC Foundation, a peer recovery program, wants to establish a facility geared towards assisting people leaving correctional facilities, the homeless, those addicted to drugs and alcohol and the disabled.
‘Stench Creek’ signs raise eyebrows in Parksville Qualicum Beach
It’s not unusual for people to complain about an unpleasant odour as they drive near the French Creek Pollution Control Centre between Parksville and Qualicum Beach, but in 2025 someone decided to take matters into their own hands.
The signs over the creek were altered to read “Stench Creek” and photos circulated on local social media groups.
The odour control upgrades, part of the French Creek Pollution Control Centre: Expansion and Odour Control Upgrades project, will begin in 2026 and be operational in spring 2027, said Belinda Woods, manager of wastewater services for the Regional District of Nanaimo.
Oceanside Sharks senior lacrosse team wins in VILL debut
Lacrosse season in the Parksville Qualicum Beach region started with a promising debut by the Oceanside Senior Sharks in the 2025 Vancouver Island Lacrosse League.
They scored 12-5 win over the Tugmen on April 15 in Victoria.
“It’s a strong start to the season,” said manager Renee Allan, who with team director Josh Heyd was excited to be able to assemble a team of 21 players and now become part of the VILL.

RDN staff work to save $7M aquatic centre grant
With majority of the voters rejecting a plan to borrow up to $30 million for the Ravensong Aquatic Centre expansion project, the Regional District of Nanaimo has to find a way to save the $7-million grant received for the major initiative from the federal government.
Electoral Area G (French Creek, San Pareil, Little Qualicum, Englishman River) alternate director Brian Wiese presented a motion that staff be directed to research an alternate project scope, with a maximum of $10 million, contingent utilizing all the $7 million funding contribution provisionally awarded to the Ravensong renovation project.
Staff presented a report on a scaled-down Ravensong project that focuses on expanding facility footprint to accommodate changeroom renovations, enhanced lobby space, two new multipurpose rooms and the structural support to accommodate a future fitness centre expansion.
Filming for season 2 of Coombs art gallery TV series nearly done
Filming will soon wrap up for the second season of a documentary series that focuses on the Coastal Carvings Fine Art Gallery and its artists.
Coastal Carvings will premiere its first 13-episode season this September on APTN, according to Jeremy Humpherville, artist and gallery owner.
The series follows the artists as they work from start to finish on a piece of art, which can take a month or two, or much longer.
Coombs-based junior horseback vaulting team prepares for world championships
The West Coast Vaulters are busy preparing to catapult themselves to glory at the 2025 FEI Vaulting World Championships in Stadl Paura, Austria from July 30 to Aug. 3.
The Coombs-based club’s young horseback vaulters who have been honing their prowess for the world competition include Autumn Southorn, Bellaku Caleb, Selina Armenta, Annika Webb, Alyssa Gaudet and Emma Ahnert.
The team’s coach is Gabe Aniello and the lunger/coach is Jessica Bentsen-Aniello.
The ages of the vaulters range from 13 to 17 years old.
